conclusion: Define O as the centre of the semicircle, A as the left-hand end of the flat base, and B as the right-hand end, with AB being a diameter of length 2R.
A ray in air is incident on the curved surface at some point P making an angle γ with the radius OP.
The ray enters the glass along OP because the curved surface is normal to OP.
Inside the glass, the ray travels along OP towards the base, strikes the base at point Q directly below P, and meets the base at an angle γ.
Only rays for which γ is smaller than the critical angle γc can emerge from the base.
The extreme ray that still emerges satisfies γ = γc.
P is the point on the semicircle where the radius OP makes the angle γ with the vertical radius OC.
The geometry gives the horizontal distance CQ = R sin γ from the midpoint of the base to the extreme emergent point Q.
Rays that reach the base between C − R sin γ and C + R sin γ leave the glass.
Beyond the range C − R sin γ and C + R sin γ, rays meet the base at angles greater than γ and suffer total internal reflection.
The width of the portion of the base through which light emerges is Δx = 2 R sin γ.
